name: Healthy
description: Plants are vigorous and photosynthesis is optimal. Focus is on prevention, balanced nutrition, and maintaining a strong canopy.
organic_treatment:
Today:
• Apply humic acid (12%) @ 2 ml/L as root drench to promote root growth.
Weekly:
• Apply Trichoderma viride @ 5 g/L as soil drench or spray to keep soil microflora healthy.
Daily:
• Maintain 5 cm organic mulch around plants to conserve moisture.
• Remove suckers up to the first V-fork to maintain a well-ventilated canopy.
chemical_treatment:
Today:
• Spray NPK 19:19:19 @ 5 g/L + micronutrient mixture @ 2 ml/L as foliar feed.
Flowering stage:
• Switch to 0:52:34 @ 5 g/L to support flowering and fruit set.
Weekly:
• Apply calcium nitrate @ 5 g/L (foliar or fertigation) to strengthen cell walls.
Always:
• After fertigation, flush lines with clean water for 30 minutes to prevent salt build‑up.
yield_advice:
• Maintain an open canopy by removing excess inner shoots.
• Check EC (1.8–2.2) and pH (6.0–6.5) of irrigation water/solution once per week.
• Harvest fruits regularly at correct maturity to keep plants in continuous production.
follow_up:
Frequency:
• Check the field every 7–10 days during normal weather.
• Increase checks to every 3–4 days after heavy rain or strong winds.
What to monitor:
• Uniform green color of leaves without spots, yellowing, or curling.
• New flush of leaves and flowers forming regularly.
• Absence of insect pests on the underside of leaves and tender shoots.
Actions:
• If any minor spots or yellowing patches appear, tag those plants for closer observation.
• Adjust irrigation if soil stays too wet or too dry around the root zone.
• Record plant vigor and flowering intensity in a simple field notebook or app.

name: Bacterial Spot
description: Systemic bacterial infection causing water-soaked necrotic spots. Spreads rapidly via water splashing.
organic_treatment:
Immediately:
• Stop overhead irrigation; switch to drip or furrow irrigation only.
Today:
• Spray Pseudomonas fluorescens @ 5 ml/L uniformly on foliage.
• Remove heavily infected leaves and dispose of them outside the field; disinfect tools between cuts.
Daily (during active infection):
• Avoid field operations when leaves are wet to prevent spreading bacteria.
• Keep the crop area weed‑free to reduce alternate hosts and humidity.
chemical_treatment:
Day 1:
• Spray Copper Hydroxide @ 2 g/L + Streptocycline @ 0.1 g/L.
Day 3–4:
• Rotate to Copper Oxychloride @ 2 g/L + Kasugamycin @ 2 ml/L.
Repeat interval:
• Repeat sprays every 5–7 days if new spots continue to appear.
Notes:
• Avoid more than 2–3 consecutive copper + antibiotic sprays to reduce resistance and residue issues.
• Always follow pre‑harvest intervals (PHI) mentioned on labels.
yield_advice:
• Stop nitrogen‑rich fertilizers immediately to prevent soft growth; switch to Potash (0:0:50) @ 5 g/L to harden tissues.
• Remove worst‑affected rows early if infection is severe to protect the remaining area.
follow_up:
Frequency:
• First detailed review 3 days after the initial spray.
• Subsequent checks every 5–7 days until no new lesions appear.
What to monitor:
• Number of new spots on young leaves compared to previous visit.
• Presence of water‑soaked halos or coalescing lesions.
Actions if improving:
• Continue rotation of recommended sprays at 7‑day interval.
• Gradually reintroduce balanced nutrition while avoiding excess nitrogen.
Actions if not improving:
• Shorten spray interval to 5 days and review spray coverage and water quality.
• Consider removing severely affected plants or patches to stop spread.

name: Early Stage
description: Localized spots appearing on lower leaves. Recovery is highly likely with immediate copper-based protection.
organic_treatment:
Evening or early morning:
• Spray azadirachtin (10,000 ppm) @ 2 ml/L as a preventive bio‑bacterial and insect deterrent.
As soon as possible:
• Plant marigold or other trap crops on borders to reduce pest pressure.
Weekly:
• Apply seaweed extract as per label recommendation to support stress tolerance.
Daily:
• Remove a few badly affected leaves per plant without heavy pruning to maintain photosynthesis.
chemical_treatment:
Today:
• Spray Copper Oxychloride @ 2 g/L + silicon‑based spreader @ 0.5 ml/L for protective coverage.
After 5 days:
• Rotate to Streptocycline @ 0.1 g/L to stop bacterial multiplication.
If sucking pests are present:
• Apply imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 0.3 ml/L (avoid peak flowering to protect pollinators).
yield_advice:
• Keep soil moist but allow the top 1–2 cm to dry slightly between irrigations.
• Apply amino‑acid tonic @ 2 ml/L once per week to help plants recover.
• Reduce nitrogen application slightly while maintaining adequate potassium and calcium.
• Scout the field at least twice per week for any increase in lesion size or number.
follow_up:
Frequency:
• Inspect the crop every 3 days for the next 2 weeks.
What to monitor:
• Whether existing lesions are staying the same size, shrinking, or expanding.
• Appearance of new lesions on previously clean leaves.
Actions if stable or improving:
• Continue the recommended rotation of bactericides.
• Gradually return to the normal fertilizer schedule while keeping good airflow in the canopy.
Actions if worsening:
• Reclassify the block as Mid Stage and switch to the Mid Stage chemical and organic protocol.
• Mark severely affected rows with flags for closer monitoring.

name: Mid Stage
description: Infection is spreading to the middle canopy. Requires aggressive bactericide rotation and strict hygiene.
organic_treatment:
Immediately:
• Prune leaves or shoots with more than 40% damage and remove them from the field.
Today:
• Drench beneficial microbes (Bacillus subtilis or Trichoderma spp.) around the root zone to support soil health.
Weekly:
• Maintain a layer of organic mulch to stabilize soil moisture and temperature.
Daily:
• Ensure strong airflow between rows and strictly avoid overhead irrigation.
chemical_treatment:
Day 1:
• Spray Kasugamycin 3% SL @ 2 ml/L OR Validamycin @ 2 ml/L as antibiotic.
Day 5:
• Rotate to Copper Hydroxide @ 2 g/L + Streptocycline @ 0.1 g/L.
Day 10:
• Apply Copper Oxychloride @ 2 g/L to provide protective coverage on new growth.
If insect vectors are present:
• Apply acetamiprid @ 0.5 g/L to reduce secondary spread.
yield_advice:
• Spray magnesium sulfate (Epsom salt) @ 5 g/L if yellowing between veins is visible.
• During flowering, add boron 20% @ 1 g/L to support fruit set.
• 3–4 days after each major chemical round, apply a mild micronutrient + amino‑acid feed.
follow_up:
Frequency:
• Inspect the field every 3–4 days until the disease is clearly under control.
What to monitor:
• Percentage of canopy affected in each plot or row.
• Rate of appearance of new lesions on young leaves and stems.
Actions if improving:
• Maintain the chemical rotation but gradually extend the interval to 7 days.
• Focus on nutrition that supports recovery (potassium, calcium, magnesium).
Actions if not improving or spreading fast:
• Treat the area as Advanced Stage.
• Consider removing heavily affected patches to protect nearby healthy plants.

name: Advanced Stage
description: Large patches of the canopy are damaged, with heavy defoliation and major yield loss. Management focuses on salvage and preventing spread to new blocks.
organic_treatment:
Immediately:
• Uproot and destroy severely affected plants that have little chance of recovery.
Today:
• Drench removed spots or pits with a mild disinfectant solution or bleaching powder (after a small safety test).
Next season:
• Plan soil solarization, crop rotation, or cover crops to reduce inoculum levels.
Always:
• Clean tools, containers, and footwear before entering healthy blocks to avoid carrying spores.
chemical_treatment:
Today:
• Spray high dose of Copper Hydroxide @ 3 g/L + Streptocycline @ 0.2 g/L thoroughly on remaining plants.
Every 4–5 days:
• Repeat sprays until no new lesions appear on fresh growth.
If soft rot or bacterial ooze is present:
• Add Kasugamycin 3% SL @ 2 ml/L in the spray tank.
Stop when:
• No new lesions appear for at least 7 consecutive days and existing lesions are dry and inactive.
yield_advice:
• Remove small, deformed, or unmarketable fruits so the plant can focus resources on remaining marketable fruits.
• Increase potassium and phosphorus supply while reducing nitrogen to harden tissues.
• Harvest all possible fruits quickly before quality declines further.
• If more than 60–70% of plants in a block reach Advanced Stage, plan to terminate that block and replant with a clean crop after sanitation.
follow_up:
Frequency:
• Check the field daily for the next 7–10 days.
• After the situation stabilizes, reduce monitoring to every 3–4 days.
What to monitor:
• Whether new infections are appearing in previously healthy rows.
• Progression of lesions on stems and fruits, not just leaves.
Actions:
• If spread continues despite full protocol, prioritize saving border rows and nearby healthy blocks.
• Mark blocks that need termination and schedule removal and deep burial or burning as per local regulations.
• Document dates of each inspection, spray, and plant removal to guide decisions in the next season.
